Let's jump out of the fantasy, fighting, and science fiction realms. Let's get back to slice-of-life!
Two middle school students really want to be the best manga artists out there because of reasons I won't tell you. Just watch this amazing show. Please.
I'll leave this review on a positive note by saying what I don't like first. The opening song feels so... old. Like a anime romance from before 1995. It's 2010. It's a good song, but it's just not right these days. It's a huge turnoff for first-timers, they won't see how good the story is!
The story is amazing because it's about growth, having dreams,reaching for your dreams, and dealing with shit that happens along the way. And hey, this is a show where the characters actually have a goal... not some "hey watch this show, it's about the daily life of..."\n\n
I like when the show ends because of the ending song, it's just so full of positive energy. I say THAT song should be the opening.\n\n
I have high hopes for this show.

I started watching this show with really high expectations and I'm pleased to announce that I was not disappointed!
"Bakuman" was created by the same duo who brought us the masterpiece known as "Death Note" (Tsugumi Ohba and Takeshi Obata) so fans can expect yet another gripping story, but this time with a few more laughs and all-around happy vibes in the mix. It follows the lives of two young boys, Moritaka Mashiro and Akito Takagi, as they start their journey to become the best manga artists Japan (if not the world) has ever seen.
My summary might not do the show any justice, but it's onlydue to my fear of revealing any spoilers.


Art: (9/10)


The art is amazing and so realistic. Only a slight difference when used for comedic effect (slapstick/ gag) but it's so well executed I doubt anyone would complain.


Sound: (9/10)


I loved all the songs used in the show, except the first OP (way too cheesy in my opinion). 


Characters and Story: (10/10)


I fell in love with all the characters as none of them were annoying or boring. Though our leading men stole the show, it just wouldn't be as successful without the supporting cast. The respect and love the characters have for one another really is something to admire, especially how Mashiro and Takagi's "rivals" motivate the two to give each project they start their all.


The intensity I felt when watching these 75 episodes made me forget that I was watching an animated show and not some live action drama!


I highly recommend  this show to any fan of the slice of life genre. No, scratch that. I recommend this show to EVERY anime fan out there. If you're looking for a great story with likeable characters, you can't go wrong with this one.

I seriously had to fight myself to not give this series a 10. To be blunt: I fricking love Bakuman.
From the creative team behind Death Note (Which I'll stop procrastinating and get to one of these days) comes this compelling tale of two crazy kids with a dream. Moritaka "Saiko" Mashiro, and Takagi, aka "Shujin" are two young boys who want to become famous manga artists. We quickly find out that they aren't BS-ing as they race toward achieving that dream. With reluctant-artist Mashiro drawing and offbeat student Takagi writing it, the two try to make it big, bonding and becoming close friends along theway.


Possibly the key factor behind this series' grandeur is how deep and realistic the characters are. Our two leads are both interesting and relatable in some way. Saiko's uncle had success as a mangaka, which inadvertently lead to his death, which leaves Saiko with the will to fulfill his dreams and also fear of failure. Shujin, on the other hand, is a high-grading student with the path of a normal life and career set out for him, but he has always had the secret dream of being a writer for the manga he loved so much. Their paths intertwine, and I don't want to spoil anything, but I'll say this: The two put everything on the line and give it their all! They have such passion and drive that their pursuit is truly inspiring.


In short, this is more than just an anime. It's a timeless story about chasing dreams and looking to the future. I felt completely invested with the characters through their ups and downs. The story is so realistic and chance-filled that there's no guessing what will happen next. It's not a fairy-tale where all dreams come true, it's real life, where all we can do is hope for the best.


And at this I have to break my heart by being fair and bringing attention to the negatives of this series. First and foremost, the start is kind of just meh...If not for generally curiosity I wouldn't have watched past the first episode (Which would've been a huge mistake on my part). Secondly, some of the other characters are less effective the art/animation isn't always spectacular. And lastly, the theme song for the anime kind of sucks. I see what they were going for and why they chose that direction, but the song is just generally dull and not memorable at all. And this would be less annoying if it weren't for the fact that the show's soundtrack is filled with other songs that would've made a way better opening (including the ending).


In the end, this series should be seen by everyone who ever had a dream, or who ever wanted to go out and do something when the odds were against them. It'll have you laughing, crying, and dreaming on.

Bakuman is a very well balanced series that introduces powerful elements of romance, suspense, and comedy. It's an animé adaption of a manga about manga, written by Tsugumi Ohba and illustrated by Takeshi Obata; the same dynamic duo that brought the world Death Note. Surprisingly, outside of its clever story telling elements, Bakuman is -nothing- like Death Note when you compare the two settings and characters. It just goes to show how amazing that these two mangaka are when it comes to variation. 
I think the story is wonderfully presented, the key to success for this series lies with the execution of the plot ratherthan the plot itself. It's well paced and has elements of everything. Not only will this series teach you a little about the manga industry, but it goes into great detail with a very strong and not quite as unique an idea as it is well presented under lining romance plot keeping the series going ahead. Aside from this, it also has the same elements of a non-mainstream 'battle' manga, in the form of authors competing against each other. It becomes really fired up as the two protagonists of this series work their fingers to the bone to come up with the best stories and characters they possibly can.


Quite a fair few of the episodes leave an air of suspense, an excitement for the next episode. There's not so much of this in the first series since it's setting the scene for the next two seasons of the show, but it really does let you get to grips with the primary characters, that are easy to relate to, you can really emphasize with them. If that doesn't float your boat, there are loads of animé and manga references too, that're used in a serious context. 


I love the art for this series, the character designs are brilliant and bring back some of that Death Note nostalgia; you can really see some similarities when it comes to how expressive the characters are, or the weird ways in which some of the more eccentric cast move. I think the backgrounds are well designed and match the series perfectly. 


I think the OST for this series is good; fitting and at times astonishing when it comes to the wide range of situations that you'll see in this series, setting the tone for the suspenseful scenes, the dramatic scenes and the passionate scenes. Bakuman really knows how to nurture the nostalgia lobe of the brain with its good selection. I'm not sure what to think of the opening and ending for season one, the opening comes across as more romantic than anything else, which I didn't really like since the romance plot is only one part of the story. I wanted something a little more upbeat, a little less serious. 


One other thing to comment on is the voice acting. When I read a manga first, I always wonder what the voices for the characters are going to be like in the animé. I'm usually disappointed by the choices but I couldn't find a single thing to complain about in Bakuman. All of the voices match the characters perfectly, the cast is spectacular and none of them bore me to tears. They're so emotional and real; they give the characters a lot more personality. 


You can always trust the writer of this series to know how to write characters with personality. Sure, there's the occasional one that pales in comparison to the rest but what you'll find in Bakuman is a cast of characters that you can actually care about. All of the authors are unique, some of them more eccentric than others, and the animé pays a close amount of attention to all of them. It's not just the authors either! The editors themselves slam their heads together, always trying to better themselves and their authors. There's so much tension between the editing department and the authors at times, it's enough to make you grind your teeth together.Just wonderful and excellent characterization. I admire how interesting is when this series throws together two completely contrasting characters, the dialogue is intense and the amount of serious humor is incredible. 


It's a very enjoyable series with 'good' everything, good enough to make you enjoy the entire product to a very high degree. In all honesty, I preferred the manga for this series but the animé doesn't lose out on anything. I think it helps if you pace yourself while watching it, because the suspense in each chapter or episode really paid off a lot more back when it was being released chapter by chapter or episode by episode. It had a strong effect on me, and made me want to see the next part so much more. 


I highly suggest this to anyone who liked Death Note, even if it's not within the same genre. I wonder what these two will come out with next; I think anything they make will be decent. If there's one thing you can expect out of this series, it's consistency.

So, this is my first review after seen about 100 anime. First I must say a couldn't be happier for finding this anime!
The story is awesome and it manage to be exciting thorough all 25 episodes. What ir really like is how they reach to give every topic enough time to develop it and not to much for been boring.
For me it was that awesome because this anime had me smiling, jumping across my room and getting me emotional almost every episode. It is now on my top 5 anime.
If you read this go watch Bakuman NOW!

No, it isn't anything to do with the capital of Azerbaijan...
I came into Bakuman. on the back of "Gekkan Shoujo Nozaki-Kun", and I expected something similar - light comedy revolving around manga. Bakuman. isn't like that at all. Instead, it's an uplifting tale about the pursuit of ambitions and dreams, and compelling enough that you should be hooked from the first episode. If you read the synopsis and liked the idea, go and watch it now - you won't be disappointed.
Bakuman.'s story isn't ground-breaking, but it is extremely well executed. The relentless pacing of the anime is excellent in creating the idea of progress towardsthe character's goals, especially during the start of the show. The show isn't afraid to show the character's hardships either, which makes the successes ever sweeter, and hooks the viewer into the cycle of ups and downs that is making manga. Bakuman.'s story is a very, very enjoyable ride.


However, the story would be nothing without memorable characters to act it out, and Bakuman. has these in spades. The central duo, Mashiro and Takagi, are extremely likeable, with infectious enthusiasm and energy throughout, and although I can't say much without giving away some sort of plot detail, the show's supporting cast are equally brilliant. Bakuman.'s characters are possibly its greatest strength - you sympathise with them, and invest yourself in their various struggles. No matter what sort of character you identify with in anime, someone in Bakuman. is guaranteed to strike a chord.


Art and Sound are good enough. The OP, "Blue Bird" is catchy enough, and fits the mood down to the ground. Bakuman.'s music becomes familiar, and gets an almost pavlovian response once you've heard it enough. Art is consistent too, though I personally think that it improves in the later series. I'm not qualified enough to say whether it's a beautifully drawn masterpiece or just serviceable, but it looks good to me.


To conclude, Bakuman. is a great anime. Its characters are well-written, its story is well-executed, and the fabulous pacing makes its message inspirational. Maybe it just struck a chord with me, but watching the characters sweat to make their dreams happen made me want to do the same - it really is that good. I pulled all-nighters to watch Bakuman., and I can't think of a better recommendation than that.

Dreams do come true if you work hard for it.  Young or old, anyone can do it.  
This anime showed me the life of aspiring mangakas and how one gambles to be serialized.  It's no easy task, there's always a trial and error to attract readers.  I learned what mangakas go through before we, as readers, get to see their work.  It's a tough job! A name must be interesting first before it gets finalize in inking.
It's a slice-of-life anime, especially if you can relate to Mashiro and Takagi of being an aspiring mangaka.  You get to see thatit's possible to balance school work and striving for your dream.


Along the way, there are parts where you already expect what might happen but because of being curious of how these two go  through the challenges, you can't stop watching.  Also, it's exciting to see whenever they receive good news.  


During the series, you can see the development between Mashiro and Takagi as partners.  How their ideas sync together to make a name that will truly earn them being  serialized.  


There are also a few details what mangakas do, especially what tools they use which is interesting.  Also, you learn a thing or to what's going on inside the editing department for mangas.  How each manga is chosen for serialization and how readers rate the chosen manga.


Overall, the story is great. It's rare to see an anime that tells about the lives behind mangakas.


I haven't read the manga yet so I don't know how the story is going to turn out.  I can't wait for the next season.

I've always enjoyed stories that are grounded, stories that are able to make me relate to the characters. To make me care about their success as if it were my own.
I can't speak for every anime or manga fan when I say this, but I know that I've always dreamed about drawing my own manga and writing my own anime. Bakuman has allowed me to live out at least a little of those dreams.
Depicting the struggles, hardwork, and perseverance, that goes into creating manga. Bakuman is a fantastic, light hearted anime, about a couple of mangaka just trying to make their dreams a reality. Throughits colourful cast of characters, good artwork, and overall strong story, Bakuman truly succeeded at making me care about the success of its characters. 


The main duo, do a good job of representing the youthful optimism of middleschoolers. These two had me very invested in their story, making me feel almost as many emotions as they did, throughout the highs and lows of their aspiring careers as mangaka. However what truly elevates this story for me, are the myriad of other interesting and fleshed out side characters, that our main duo interact with during their journey. These characters range from young mad geniuses overflowing with talent, to older artists who still have yet to lose their passion for chasing their dreams. 


If I had to give some criticism to this anime (which I do, this is in fact the point of a review) it would be that, this story could have benefited from being slightly more serious. Despite our cheerful and determined main characters, the show actually started with a rather bleak outlook, one which I would have liked to see stay. Honestly, despite showing lots of the hardwork that mangaka really have to do to survive, let alone standout within their field. The show actually holds back on some of the more serious aspects of the industry. I know part of the decision is because of the young age of our main characters, but still I can't help but wish they had been made maybe a little older, so that we could see some of the darker parts of being a mangaka.


I give this anime an 8/10. A solid and engaging story from start to finish. It truly had me on the edge of my seat at times and laughing my ass off at others. I would recommend this anime to anyone looking for a little bit of motivation in their lives and those who would simply like some good fun.


PS: If you want more context for my scores out of 10, please visit my profile.

How anyone could give this anime above a 6 is beyond me. My review is primarily based upon the first season, as I have dropped it mid-way through season 2. I also have not read the manga.
I don't write reviews often, but this is the first time I've felt so betrayed by the scoring this anime has gotten on MAL. Now, I wasn't expecting an action packed shounen. I read the description, and I thought it was a unique and original approach to the genre. Watching the adventures of two boys striving to become famous mangaka was, for me, both realistic and inspiring.
Needless to say,I was sorely disappointed in the execution of the story. The pacing was agonizing slow, and there seemed to be no real progression. Although I understand shounen requires buildup, this was atrocious. It was nauseating to have to sit through each episode, hoping that the next would be better. I kept telling myself to just wait it out... just wait it out.


Although I understand the characters endeavors contain setbacks, they were very linear. There were no suggestions for an alternative route (really, you can't think of any other place or company to start other than Shonen Jump?). There was nothing refreshing after their failures... you just grit your teeth as they try the same thing again. Bring in a school event, or take them to an art exhibit in Tokyo... ANY change of scenery for pete's sake.


 If there was anything worse than the story execution, it was the character dynamics. The main character is an unappealing narcissist with literally no redeeming qualities. Luckily Takagi and Miyoshi provide something light and refreshing with their quirky natures. Miho makes me want to jab my eyes out with how two-dimensional she is as the main characters love interest. How is this anime fit to be called a romance, when there's more romance between the side characters than the main one.


Moving on, the art was mediocre for its age, and the animation was far from amazing. The sound and music isn't anything significant to make notice, as it leaves little to no impression on the viewer.


Story: 6

Art: 5

Sound: 2

Character: 1

Enjoyment: 1

Overall: 5

Bakuman is overall one of the most well-rounded best anime i've ever seen. Throughout the anime we see Mashiro and Takagi go through the trials of becoming mangaka. From season 1 to season 3 we see Mashiro work towards a dream he and Miho Azuki made in middle school that one day Miho would voice in one of Mashiro's anime, then get married. Also coincidentally, Mashiro's late uncle Nobuhiro was a "gambling" mangaka with the exactsame dream as Mashiro with Miho's mother.


It is honestly hard for me to point out the cons of this anime.. but here you go. The only time I was not completely interested in this anime while watching it was during the beginning/middle of season 3. During this time the story felt slightly stale in my opinion. I believe the reason for this was the story became far less focused on Miho as she slowly drifts away until towards the end of the anime. While she was away the story felt 100% focused on their creation of manga and became slightly repetitive. I fully recommend this anime for everyone to watch! Also, I would like to say that Takeshi and Tsugumi are two genius mf's.


Overall Rating 9/10

BAKUMAN!!!!!
The three series of Bakuman are a must watch. First off i will give a small synopsis and then go into how important this show really means too the anime/ manga community. Bakuman is a story of two school boys who both have dreams to have a successful manga to be serialized in Jack.So both come together to form a team with  Moritaka Mashiro being the artist and Akito Takagi being the author. The two also have there own goals with the main one being an anime adaptation of there manga so Moritaka can Mary his love interest Azuki who wants to be apopular voice actor. The story follows Mashiro's and Akito struggles and successes right from them being in middle school until they are adults. With comedy, romance and a feel good story, Bakuman will be all that you can watch. I highly rate this show especially to Veteran anime watchers. \n\n
The reason why I highly regard Bakuman is that it gives an in depth look at how difficult the lives of manga authors and artists are. I think Tsugumi Ohba and Takeshi Obata who wrote and illustrated Bakuman provide an in depth look behind the difficulties of Manga artists/authors, demonstrating how its not a job but a love or obsession. To be honest the manga and anime are both superb to create feelings for the character and actually want to cheer you on. With new characters and rivals being introduced this will always be a unique and sensational anime.

An anime about making manga, with all the gamble, dreams and effort that goes into it, this is Bakuman.
Bakuman is definitely one of the earliest "working anime" anime LA heard of before Shirobako for anime about anime and Sora ga Seiyuu! for anime about voice acting. Bakuman is about the struggles and dreams of Akito Takagi voiced by Satoshi Hino and Moritaka Mashiro voiced by Atsushi Abe wanting to become mangaka, more specifically Shounen Jump ohh LA means Shounen Jack. They face and work with their rivals, strict editorials "missions" and deadlines, hard work into their manga's as well as the process of even makingdifferent kinds of manga in the process. 


Although Takagi's dream is just to be a mangaka  (more on the writers side of things) by working together with Mashiro and getting rich with it, Mashiro (the illustrator) has another goal of wanting a manga to be serialized as a promise for him and his love interest Miho Azuki voiced by Saori Hayami to be the lead heroine and then get married after. Sure it adds in the romance element into this anime but it works for a huge degree for Mashiro's ambitions to be the best in Shounen Jack and his goal striving for him to do be number 1#.


Now you'd think this anime is nothing but the intricacies of making manga, how Shounen Jack handles their manga and whatnot and it does but it also greatly develop their core cast and rivals as well. Some of the biggest surprises for LA for characters would go to Takagi and Kaya Miyoshi voiced by Sayuri Yahagi as they actually get together quite early on and with Kaya wanting to full out support Takagi and Mashiro venture into the strict and volatile world of shounen manga (this and because Kaya is best friends with Miho). Next would be Takagi and Mashiro's rivals more specifically Eijii Nizuma voiced by Nobuhiko Okamoto and Shinta Fukuda voiced by Junichi Sawabe. Eijii for being Takagi and Mashiro's primary rival in the early episodes as Eijii is a genius yet hyperactively unfocused mangaka but becoming a sorta frienemy mentor to them later on and Takagi and Mashiro striving to be better than Eijii. Fukuda is more in line the actual rival to Takagi and Mashiro as he's alot more serious in wanting to be serialized like Takagi and Mashiro's goal for this season. Really in essences this anime season really doesn't have the typical rival scthick where the rival is the "bad guy" while making Takagi and Mashiro look better, each of their rivals had their quirks and styles of manga even making their rivals have more than the one dimensional personality of a rival making them to be memorable in a ways (well the exception is Koogy voiced by Shoutarou Morikubo but he never directly confronted Takagi and Mashiro in saying their his rival or his ethnics in making manga was the wrong way to do it etc.) 


The other surprising notion is that both of Takagi and Mashiro's respective love interests aren't just one-dimensional cheerleaders. Again there's Kaya and how she supports their ventures into manga but she has personality outside being one of their cheerleader for them (by that, she your typical brutish tsundere but definitely more on the dere side and her even wanting to be a writer like Takagi) and even sometimes causes rifts between Takagi and Mashiro through Takagi wanting to take his relationship with Kaya more seriously while not concentrating on manga. Miho on the other hand, although in this season she's IS a sideline cheerleader love interest for Mashiro, Miho has her own ambitions of being a voice actor so she can be the lead heroine of Mashiro's serialized manga turn anime and she too faces adversity and fears by being an "amateur voice actor" albeit not in great detail to Mashiro's journey to be serialized.


And finally, LA would like to point out that even the editors of Shounen Jack develops along with their respective mangaka but the best focused ones goes to Takagi and Mashiro's editor Akira Hattori and Yuujirou Hattori, Eijii Nizuma and Shinta Fukuda's editor and Hisashi Sasaki voiced by Kenyuu Horiuchi the Editor-in-Chief of Shounen Jack gets some focus (mainly business-supportive-wise NOT personally of course). What else can LA say but the obvious for Bakuman, character development is excellently done even for this HUGE cast of mangaka's, editors, love interests and rivals of the sort get the subtle detail treatment and LA loves it!.


The animation done by JC Staff is greatly done in almost every front, from the slick character designs to the manga's that many of the mangaka's gives out are in superb quality, better yet are many of the scenes where people are reading the manga (and voice acted out in people's heads) and the manga is shown to great detail as well. JC Staff really outdid themselves with the animation and manga aesthetics with this one.


The voice work was also pretty great with no grating annoying voices in sight. Highlights would go to Atsushi Abe and Satoshi Hino of course, but the craziest voice actor easily goes to Nobuhiko Okamoto doing an almost 24/7 "Awakened Level 5 Accelerator" vocals on Eijii Nizuma...just JESUS Nobuhiko go all out with this one. However LA's favourite voice actors would go to Sayuri Yahagi as Kaya...because of her deredere vocals being amazing alright..simple as that.


Ok, LA didn't find many faults with Bakuman but just one little thing that kinda dumbfounded LA about Bakuman would be why Shounen Jump was changed to Shounen Jack, because here's the thing, Bakuman namedrops ALOT of manga from Shounen Jump, from Naruto, Bleach to One Piece and they even have manga covers showing them yet Jump changed to Jack?, was it because JC couldn't get the "license" to have Jump namedropped but their titles instead or that Jump just didn't want unblazened advertising in an anime because that would be unfair advertising for other manga magazines?, which doesn't makes sense due to Shounen Jump's titles being referenced alot but not Jump itself?...LA doesn't know WHY but still irked LA they changed it.


However if there is one little fault LA could see and this is entirely LA's perspective and that is Mashiro and Miho's long distance relationship as it were. LA already defended this relationship as Miho and Mashiro both have their own ambitions that leads into their dream, however besides the two being the cheerleaders on both sides, their interactions largely consisted of being twice shy and only rarely opening up to each other but being supportive nonetheless. LA isn't saying this relationship is horrible or anything and LA is sure this relationship would develop further from this in the next season but you can see why LA kinda already favoured Kaya and Takagi more due to their fast process and taking it further than most anime romances do even for a beta couple.


Bakuman is the gamble of the imagination taken real form, of dreams coming true be for the riches or the glory of being serialized. Bakuman is by all means a GREAT anime about looking at the inner workings of the manga industry and it's mangaka's and with fully fleshed out characters, a concentrated focused plot from both it's shounen and romantic aspects and intensity and anticipation of many of the competitions of the best manga being serialized. LA just can't wait to watch the second season!.

Bakuman is written by Tsugumi Ohba and illustrated by Takeshi Obata, the same creative teamresponsible for the popular anime/manga Death Note.(Similar character designs-- Mashiro--L, and Takagi--Light Yagami)

Bakuman is a shonen anime about creating a first rate manga and someday turning that manga into an anime series. With the added bonus of Slice of life and romcance.  This anime teaches you how a manga artist goes through in life into creating a manga. Our story revolves around  Mashiro and Takagi who team up together to pursue their dream of creating a manga series that will rival popular manga like Naruto, Bleach, One Piece, Dragonball and Hunter X Hunter. They hope to one day  to serialize it and turn it into an anime. But they have a rival Nizuma Eiji who is a manga prodigy and creating new manga left and right.  Mashiro and Takagi goal is to beat Nizuma  Eiji and be number one in Mainstream manga. They meet the editor of Yushia(Shueshia) Shonen Jack(Jump) Hattori who helps them make their manga better.!!!!This anime is captivating and inspirational and teaches the hardship a manga artist goes through daily. 


Have you ever wonder how legendary Mangka artist- Kishimoto's Naruto, Kubo's Bleach,  Oda's One Piece, Gintama went though in creating their manga, Well every mangka artist all go through the same process. Meeting certain deadlines or risking getting cancelled!!!  Creating a manga takes months and needs a lot of time and effort.  Manga artist aren't known yet until they publish their first manga. Like with Mashiro and Takagi- their manga needs to critiqued and if needed make any necessary changes to make it better. 


This is one of the most addicting/inspirational  anime I have ever seen. Making me wanting to watch the next episode. I am so glad there is Bakuman season 3

This review pertains to all 3 seasons of Bakuman.
The story is one that puts a lot of focus on the relationships between the individuals rather than on the plot as a whole. This leads to there being a large number of characters that are well developed and you become very emotionally invested in.
The art is adequate, but there is nothing particularly breathtaking about it. This doesn't take away from the story at all, and in fact may be a boon because it does not distract the viewer from the story.
The mood and emotional aspect of the anime is not only appropriate, but also exceptionally balanced.It isn't a simple tragedy or comedy, and the ups and downs don't feel out of place. Again this is a boon because even though you will feel for the characters, it won't end up putting off or cause the story to lose focus.\n\n
Overall it is an enjoyable series that is really a complete package. \n
In terms of priority for viewing the priority should not be very high unless you wish to get a view into the lives of manga authors.\n\n
This is why I definitely recommend that everyone who reads manga or watches anime watches this or reads the manga. It allows you to appreciate just how much work goes into what we often give barely any heed, the fact that the authors also have to make a living.

This anime has everything you ask for: love, comedy, and every bit of slice of life. You get to see how manga is made, which you don't see everyday at all and this tells you a lot on how artists strive for success to make them. Coming from Shonen Jump! And the original manga series is by the creator of Death Note, you'll see some familiar titles and skits of there manga brands in the series. 
The music and sounds are not annoying either it fits the scenes accordingly well from start to finish. 
Unforgetable characters and for some reason I liked Fukada from theseries. Guess he is just swag is all along with Nizuma Eiji. CROoOoW! \n

Not everyone is gonna agree with me here but luckly anime is a very very subjective thing even though it seems most or all of us gravitate towards certain things we want in anime. I will just say straight up this show is very personal and just how I love Barakumon I love these shows that focus on hard work, effort, struggle, inspiring, and it just makes you want to not waste your time so this review is very bias.
I really dont have to make a comment on the art its perfect for this type of show and sets the atmosphere well. I like howit feels bright and even in the dark scenes the lighting gives off that they are moving forward and with them its not ever a give up mentality. The art and lighting is not boring as in many slice of lifes where the color adds a sense of being monotone. Its a happy story and should have happy art.\n\n

This anime is probably one of the best I have seen in a while.  I can honestly say that it's the first anime that I have seen in a really long time that has kept me so addicted and enticed.
This anime is good for every anime and manga fan in several ways.  The first reason being that it's really educational.  We see a lot of fans bashing mangaka and not giving them as much of their appreciation as much as they should.  In watching just the first season, I have learned so much manga and the trials that mangaka go through.There are things I would have probably never learned if I didn't watch Bakuman.


Watching Bakuman has made me appreciate manga and anime more than ever did before, and it also makes me appreciate the mangaka more.  I have learned through Moritaka Mashiro and Akito Takagi that mangaka really do work hard and that they deserve more than what the settle for and receive from their fans.


The character development is well done, and coming from Ohba Sensei, who did a poor portrayal of females in Death Note, even the females were written well!  I don't particularly dislike any character because I think they all have something special to offer to the series.


The plot is well-written, although it's often slow at times.  However, there are simple and delicate scenes that are going to boil your blood with excitement.


Overall, I would recommend this anime to everyone who is curious about learning more about the manga and anime world.  It's definitely one of my favorite anime, and everything about it was simply exquisite.

Now if it was a characteristic of the MC or was reserved forthe MC it wouldnt be so bad , but the fact so many characters do it , drove me insane.  It truly was a stupid quality about the anime . Watching the first few episodes of Bakuman lead me to read the manga (at least the first 117 chapters).  Both are first rate, although the pace of the manga strikes me as slower than that of the the anime.  I've watch the available anime episodes several times and read the manga two or three times.  I think this is going to turn out to be one of my favorites.  The slow pace doesn't bother me much as it seems entirely appropriate to the story and characters.  The internal interaction of the artist/writer team is believable and Kaya is a greatinfluence on the team.  Miho is perfect as the embodiment of the "dream" ideal which drives Ashirogi Muto.


The anime has followed the manga very closely (some deviations are to be expected).


Although this has a long way to go (glad to see a 2nd season has been approved) I expect to follow it all the way.  There is something to be said for slow, careful character development and this work (IMHO) proves that it is worth doing.


This is a first-class work, and although it may disappoint those who prefer a much faster pace, I hope the producers/authors maintain their careful development of this story.  


Long term, I strongly expect this will become a classic!

While the anime is still fresh on my mind, I think this is the perfect time to create a review out of it.
"Never judge an anime without watching it first." - I guess this is the lesson that slapped me hard on my cynical face after I marathon-ed all three seasons of Bakuman in five days. (Yes, it seems like my "no life" status as a social being is nearing the permanent mark).
I've heard this anime many times over, but I was hesitant to watch it. I dunno, the story just wasn't interesting at first glance, I guess. I was not entirely interested in theprocess of manga-making before (and for some strange reason, I was living under a rock for years because I was not aware that the same duo that created the masterpiece that is "Death Note" was the mastermind of this yet another masterpiece. Stupid.).


Anyway, now that I got to dive to this anime masterpiece, which introduced to me whirlwind of emotions, I'm having a hard time, yet again, to find an anime of this caliber.


That makes me sad and glad all at the same time.


Anyway, let me break down my subjective review:


Story: 10

"YES!" Echoes me a few days ago when I finally absorbed the first three critical minutes of Bakuman. And I say "critical", because the make or break of an anime for me is the first three minutes. I could then gauge how much I would enjoy it. And enjoy it, I did.


Bakuman is a coming-of-age anime that lets you experience growth, struggle, hardship, friends and conflicts that life throws at you in a chase to reach for your dreams. Though the romance part was a bit over-the-top for me (even though I'm a huge sucker for romance - blame my gender!), everything else in the anime worked well to a highly intensive degree. And my little qualms about the romance were easily discarded on the last season because the characters more than made up for them (couldn't really explain it to people who hadn't watched it yet). Let's just say that the characters were strong enough that the ridiculous improbability of the romance was justified at the end. (Why was I focusing on the romance when all the other parts of the story were ingeniously made?)


The execution of scenes, the cliffhangers, and how there were no unnecessary scenes were excellently crafted. 


JUST. WONDERFUL.


Anyway, for people who hadn't watched it yet (and who lives under a rock, like me), my advice is to...


JUST WATCH IT!


...


...


...


NOW!


...


...


...


WHAT ARE YOU DOING? STOP STARING AT THIS REVIEW! JUST GO WATCH IT, STUPID!


(Sorry about  the "stupid". I don't mean it.)


Art: 9


So, you stayed to read the other parts of this review? Don't blame me if all I'll do is to gush on the masterpiece caliber of this anime.


Tonikaku (Anyway...)


So I chose 9 for art. Why is that, you ask?


I'm assuming you've all seen Death Note (who doesn't?), and you know by now how wonderful the art for that one was. So why not ten for this? I guess because, even though this is an anime about making manga, nothing stands out on the characters' designs. But it more than makes up for the "mangas" the main characters were creating - the art for those were superb.


Basically, I just gave 9 so as to leave 1 point room for improvement.


Sound: 10

Perfect for every scenes. Can't say much, but the songs used for the "mangas" and "animes" featured in the show were very-well suited to their respective genres.


Characters: 10

Hard working characters doing all that they could to reach for their dreams. Their visions and values are above the norm, and outstanding execution of their growths. They simply grow on you.


The friendly competitions, and sticking to their solid values are a joy to behold. You wouldn't hate ANYONE in this anime. (Maybe except for Iwase...)


And who wouldn't dote on Eiji, right? *Crow! Roger!*


If I were to criticize just one thing, it will be how the female characters were portrayed. (The females in this story are not really how we are, y'know?) Seems like the anime does not get that we are not that stubborn, or cold, or weak (yes, I am referring to Aoki at the first parts, and to Iwase ... even at the end).


I dunno... I just feel that the author don't get us girls. 


Nevertheless, aside from the anime's slight prejudice to the female gender, the overall characterizations were flawless. There were no stereotype characters, and each one them a different, tasty flavor.


Ashirogi Muto (Azuki, MaSHIro, TakaGI Reaching Dreams) is a penname that will resonate for me in ages.


Enjoyment: 10

This is an obvious score, considering all my gushing above.

(Love is a strong word, but for this anime, I'd say... I FREAKING LOVE IT TO THE HIGHEST DEGREE!!!)


Overall: 10

Please help me. I can't find anime at par with this. *sniffs*

[This is my first time writing a review, sorry if it is messy] [Spoiler-FREE]
"Bakuman." also known as gambling manga is about two friends trying to create a manga. After watching the 3 seasons and all 75 episodes (no regret), I have continuously been inspired by this anime and so have my friends.
I love the story, it is very simplistic and easy to understand. At the start of the anime, Mashiro Moritaka (Saiko) promises Miho Azuki that they will marry if Mashiro manages to get an anime adaptation with the help of Akito Takagi.
This show perfectly explains the ups and downs of life and how ifyou do not move on, you won't get anywhere.

There are some laughable gags here and there (that make up the comedy tag) and there are also serious scenes about friendship and being heart-broken. [9]


 I didn't mind the art, it followed the original source's art style closely (unlike Death Note, sorta). I don't have much to say about it but it fit well with the anime. [7]


The voice acting was great and it had suitable music and OSTs for specific scenes. It fit well. [7]


Oh, characters! This anime had a wide range of personalities, like being hardworking or lazy, or being enthusiastic to the max! I couldn't bring myself to hate any character at all as all of their personalities fit well with the storyline and charactern designs. [9]


I definitely enjoyed this and would wish to rewatch it when I can! [10]


Overall, love it! [10]

Close your eyes and imagine i'm sliding my han....Oops sorry,my bad lads wrong script..I meant close your eyes and imagine for a second that the creators of Death Note met once again and decided to collaborate on an anime called Bakuman with a . at the end for some reason..
"Aha",you might say,"why should i bother,it will be the same shit all over again"...And that's exactly what i thought at first..And i couldn't be more wrong,which incidentaly has never happened since 1985 or so..
No,as it happens they are also capable of mashing our brains with other kind of stories as well and this anime is theliving proof for it.And surprises keep on coming if you stop and think that Bakuman is an anime adaptation of a manga about a duo whose goal is to make a manga with the aim of eventually getting an anime adaptation..How freakin' nuts is that?


As for the story?Well it's the story of Mashiro Moritaka who after his beloved uncle's death-who was also a mangaka-was left in a dark place,battling with crippling depression and no cares for his future even though he is a brilliant artist.What he does instead is spending his time fantasizing about Azuki Miho,a girl he has a visible crush on and not only that..He also paints some pics of her and that to be honest is kinda creepy..One fateful day,he forgets a notebook containing his drawings of her in class and when he goes back to get it he sees Takagi Akito,his classmate and the top student in the school,waiting for him holding his notebook.Takagi agrees to keep Mashiro’s secret,on the condition that they'll team up and make a manga..Pretty straightforward and almost down to earth if you think about it.


As you can see the connection with Death Note is just in names only cause the whole concept is totally different,it's more lighthearted.This is-in my mind-an anime targetted mostly for those who read manga,and more specifically Shounen Jump where Bakuman was actually first serialised.In the anime itself it's being referenced as "Jack" and it's a weekly publication in Japan with a variety of manga including Naruto,One Piece and Bleach among many other titles.Having your work portrayed in a magazine of this caliber then is a big deal.And one thing that stood out to me was that many of those anime where also making an appearance here which struck me as a bit of an advertisment exercise.


Another thing that stood out to me in a very bad way was the romance part of Bakuman.Who in their right mind goes to his crush's house to tell her that if they achieve their dreams they'll get married..No previous interactions involved that would excuse such a remark..And get that...She responded in a positive way..Which ultimately means that either there are people out there crazy enough to go through the ordeal of marriage cause reasons or that the writers were being idiotic on purpose..That there for me was one of the very first shortcomings and one that came close to ruining a big chunk of my interaction with the characters themselves.


The other thing was the main duo's hierarchy and character traits.Mashiro and Takagi have a good chemistry between them but individually they’re not the most likable of personalities and this is more evident with Mashiro whose competitiveness comes close to becoming obssesive taking people down with him.Takagi is a much more likable character,but for some reason the writers thought it would be good?! for him to take back seat even though he was the one to lead the charge in the first place...As for the female counterparts,Azuki is very much underused-for lack of better words-and i can't help but think that she plays more a plot point rather than an actual,you know,character...Like she should be.I can scarcely recall her being on screen to be honest.As for Miyoshi?Think of her as the classic case of tomboy with explosive anger issues(not really,she just kicks and punches Takagi sometimes)who has no idea what she's going to do with her life and ends up serving coffee to the main duo while they're working on their mangas..And i hate to keep coming back to this but the "romance" thingy between Azuki and Mashiro was unbelievably idiotic..As down to earth romances go this far surpasses in ridiculousness the ones seen in Kanon...And most of you here know just how much i hated that crap.


As for the main antagonist..Let's say he's a genius type of teenager who makes otakus' penises run wild while aiming for the same publication spot as our duo at the same time..Apart from that...How can i put this in a gentle manner...HE IS A FUCKING RETARD.Every single time he hits the screen he does so with animal screams..And i don't mean once or twice,that would be tolerable to some extent...But no,this fuck does it A-L-L T-H-E F-U-C-K-I-N-G T-I-M-E.


Now that doesn't say much about the story as a whole cause everything else is pretty much great..And i do mean great.


In fact Bakuman does its' best when it's going for the story it was supposed to in the first place..The makings of manga.From making the manga itself to the innards of manga industry and i have to say that i was glued to my screen each and every moment because i could somehow relate to these guys and their struggles.Bakuman is by no means,shape or form a bad anime..It's just that it could be much much better and that's a pity if you ask me.Ok i wasn't expecting Shirobako levels of achievement but there were some glaring issues that held it back.


Going to VA's and animation as well as music themes...All very very good.The animation and the music feel a bit old but that has to do with the writers intent of making this feel a bit old school and know what?It freakin' works like a charm and the VA's are there to make the experience even better with their delivery.


To sum it up Bakuman is great as an anime.Sure it could be wayyyyyyyy much better in terms of characters as they seem to lack common sense and in many cases emotion.Like i said it's no Shirobako and i didn't expect one to be honest.There are 2 more seasons ahead so i hope they fixed those issues.


Definitely reccomend it

All of the characters in Bakuman are cardboards, and there isn’t any depth to visuals either.  But, the story is as subversive as you are going to get in anime with a premise like this out there.  It just simply energizes its cliché-infested writing and one-dimensional characters via unpredictable arcs that continue throughout the three seasons.  Yes, the show abounds with cringy movements, most of the drama is forced, and conflicts often play themselves out in a predictable way. Yet, before all of this saps the interest of percipient, it steers the story into an altogether interesting turn and you are hard-pressedto not to continue this totally shallow-but-fun-&-ridiculous & crazy & fun-ride.  In other words,  Bakuman, as a work of pop-culture, that revolves around the mania surrounding an aspect of sub-pop-culture( i.e. manga), has all of the best machinations of its ilk that go into the manipulating the interest of gullible audience and not so gullible ones, who  nevertheless stick with it,  because the shit is totally theirs to embrace, for all of the nuggets of satisfaction that one achieves after having wasted the precious time of their schedule, which would have been otherwise far better pad off, had they the time, dedication, and above all, intellect, to engage with its infinitely better counterpart – film!  But who can blame them, eh? I mean one can skip half of the story in Bakuman, and still get a kick out of it. It’s THAT amazing!


The lead pair is, basically, so sentimentally twisted in their genericism that you’d get these homoerotic creeps out of the banality they spew out to one another.  And one doesn’t even bother to raise an eyebrow for all the demonstrably contrived but oh-so-crucial moments that outline their friendship as a bond too indefatigable yet subject to the flaws of their individual person, except that the minutiae of realism portrayed here is handled so sloppily that any credence accorded to those moments is lost.  But this assessment literally becomes a joke when you are egotistical & ignorant enough to love these characters and love to see them going through the tribes and tribulations which will end with them to be finally licking the chalices of popularity, which supposedly corresponds to their artistic merit – one of the basic posits of this show, and the ultimate goal of characters.


That is why Bakuman is a quintessential pop-culture propaganda.

Made by the same creators of the Death Note Manga/Anime franchise, Bakuman is a great way for people how to learn to make their very own Manga: stories, drawings, characters, you name it.
Bakuman reveals the process of how a weekly Manga series is made and how it becomes an Anime, it reveals how popularity is key to both Manga and Anime alike in a Weekly Shonen Jump (renamed Jack in the series) magazine format.
The story is about hard work, determination, guts, luck and taking gambles on said luck, it is also the story of keeping promises till the very end, now even though it maynot be possible in real life to always keep a promise, Bakuman can nevertheless be inspiring in that regard.


Bakuman is the story of four individuals, two couples, as they take a journey through the worlds of both Manga and Anime creating respectively, two young men who dream of one day surpassing Mangaka authors in terms of quality and heart added to their stories, namely for examples Akira Toriyama of Dragon Ball, Eiichiro Oda of One Piece, Masashi Kishimoto of Naruto, Tite Kubo of Bleach and so on, so forth.


These two young men's names are Moritaka Mashiro and Akito Takagi and together they make up the Mangaka duo Muto Ashirogi with Moritaka serving, as the drawer of their Manga and Akito serving, as the writer of their stories.


Whether by chance or fate, Moritaka meets Akito and because of certain circumstances, they decide to team up with one another and form Muto Ashirogi which they use, as their pen name to refer to themselves together, separately they go by the pen names Saiko for Moritaka and Shujin for Akito respectively.


Although they are both the main protagonists, the story focuses more on Saiko and sees both things and life in general from his point of view, he has always wanted to be a Mangaka author and follow in the footsteps of his role model, now teaming up with Shujin, Saiko has a chance to make it big in the Manga world and prove that both he and Shujin have what it takes to surpass even the professionals.


However, they are not the only ones gunning for the top seats and ranks of the Manga world, as they face off against other friendly rival Mangaka authors, namely in particular their peer one year older then them named Eiji Niizuma who already at his age is considered the youngest genius there is in terms of Manga creativity, his skill is rival to none, of which inspires both Muto Ashirogi and all other rivalries to try and surpass Niizuma, to prove that they are not just saying they're aiming for the top spot but that they are actually going to do it, come hell or high water.


Besides the goal of surpassing Niizuma and all others, Saiko has a personal stake in why he draws Manga and why he is determined to reach the number one rank of greatest created published Manga of all time ever, he is determined to win both the heart and love of a childhood sweetheart of his named Miho Azuki who reciprocates Mashiro's feelings.


However, Miho wanted to prove to both herself and Saiko that to prove their love is genuine and special, because Saiko has always wanted to be a Mangaka author and Miho has always wanted to be a Anime Seiyu voice actress, Miho has Saiko promise her that they will not become a couple until they have both obtained their dreams and goals for the future, to ensure the promising of one another to each other.


Kind of beating around the bush yet at the very same time being pushed right up against it, know what i mean? even so, despite this roundabout way of doing things just to prove each other's love for one another, you could say from one perspective that its a cute way of looking at romance, if i'm not doing good job explaining about the two's way of romance, forgive me, the best way to better clarify what i'm trying to say is by seeing Bakuman and watching for yourself, to judge and see what you make of the whole idea of the promise and what's behind it.


Either way, Muto Ashirogi shows extreme dedication and research to their work on Manga whilst trying to create their very own and get it published in the most popular of weekly Manga magazines, they persevere through trial and error time and time again, never stopping and never once giving up on their aspirations both towards and for the future.


Besides Saiko and Miho's romance is romance also budding on Shujin's side, as Miho's best friend named Kaya Miyoshi falls in love with him, thus bringing the story of four individuals, two couples full circle.


Story, Art, Sound, Character, Enjoyment and Overall all deserve praise and whilst Bakuman may not rank highly, as its predecessor counterpart series Death Note, in honest opinion, i say that Bakuman stands, as a series all on its own, its has a warm heart and charm and might, not 100% guaranteed but might make you have warm fuzzy feelings towards the romance featured in the story.


But lastly back to the core of Bakuman, its creativity in telling a series about how people draw Manga and how Anime follows soon afterwards...Bakuman is a great way of researching Manga creative study processes whilst catching a few laughs in the process too, it will teach up and coming Mangaka authors the basics in the makings of potential great Manga series, either published by magazine or solely published by one person or a team alone on the internet, a good example being for the latter case the Mangaka author ONE who created One Punch Man but that will be saved for that series' Review later on.


At any rate, i hope my Review was helpful and sorry about it being longer then most of the Reviews i make, i also hope that it will help serve in any way possible to inspire potential new Mangaka authors right around the corner.
