A really realistic anime and one that all of us can take away from, Bakuman tells the story of two shounen who aim to become mangakas in the competitive world of manga.
Story: 7
Bakuman's story is super slowly paced throughout the entire anime, but that is a part of what makes it so realistic. The two boys fail again and again, but they learn from each failure and come back better than before. 
It takes a really long time for them to finally get somewhere, but boy is it satisfying to see when they do get there! The story is continuedin the following seasons, so I would recommend watching the sequels.



Character: 8

All the characters get great development throughout the series! 


At the start, Mashiro is a confidence-lacking artist who wants to become a mangaka but is too afraid for a reason (that is kind of a spoiler!!). Takagi, the other main character, gives Mashiro the confidence he needs to start working towards their dreams. 

By the end of the anime, we have two strong characters that have come a long way from the start, but still acknowledging room for improvement and the next leg of their journey.


The side characters are not neglected and also make up an important part of the anime. I'm going to give a shoutout to some of my favorite side characters: Niizuma, Hattori, Fukuda, and Miyoshi!


Seeing the boys progress and grow really inspired me to not give up on my own dreams, and to learn from my failures and how to better myself from them.



Animation: 7

The animation isn't really my preferred style of anime art, but it is good and makes the anime enjoyable.



Sound: 7

Bakuman's OP/ED/soundtracks weren't particularlly memorable, but they did add help add the right emotions to some scenes. 

The voice acting was great! Niizuma's voice acting was the one that stood out to me and my favorite!



Enjoyment: 7

Since the story was pretty slow through the entire anime, I did get a bit bored at some parts and took a long time finishing this anime. 

The comedy is pretty good too, and added to my enjoyment of this anime.



Bakuman is an anime that should be on everyone's list. Though it is kind of draggy and should not be watched when you're hungry for action anime, I believe everyone should see it because of its themes that can help bring you through when life if tough.

Enter Bakuman.
A creation that has shocked many people, and I’ll tell you, it shocked me too. I will be reviewing the whole series, as they all have the same plot and it will be weird if I did just one season. This anime is what you call a good creation, and somewhat impressive, and this review will tell you exactly why.
Story: 9/10
I find the story rather impressive, as it did a great job. However, there was something missing. I know! It didn’t live up much to my expectations. I expected a romance shonen anime that I would want to watch over and over again, butfor this anime, it didn’t do that, but still, the story is impressive and I think they did a really good job on the story.


Art: 9/10

The animation was amazing, but it still didn’t live up to what I expected. I don’t want to explain in details, but in short, I wanted something beautiful that will stay in my memories forever. Sure, it did that, but not really what I wanted. As for the positive things, the art looks like it was drawn by a master artist. Sure, it wasn’t much of a beauty, but it was really well animated. To me, the animation gets better time-to-time, but it is still really good.


Character: 10/10

They did the characters perfectly! They all fit what they really are! The voices, the personalities, presentation, everything! It is absolutely outstanding and brilliant, I think the characters are possibly one of the best parts of the anime, and each character makes a good story, a really good anime. I personally love the characters, they’re just beautiful.


Sound: 7/10

Okay, the soundtrack is somewhat impressive, but it didn’t impress me THAT much. Though the music can sometimes be calm and lovely, that’s just it. Some are upbeat, and some are calm, the end. I wanted more of the sound, but on the upside, all of the soundtrack is amazing, but I wanted more! It is so good, but that’s all? It deserved a 7, considering that they put in a ton of good work.


Enjoyment: 8/10

I actually enjoyed the anime, but it didn’t astonish me much. But still, I got shocked on how beautiful the anime is, but still, it didn’t surprise me much with surprise attack. As for the positive, I actually loved watching this anime. It just reminds me that there are so many manga I haven’t read yet, and it just tells me to start reading some. It also tells me that manga is not all about other people, it just has to be interesting. I was filled with joy watching each episode, and I love the anime a lot. Even if it’s not the best.


Counting all of them: Story, Animation, Character, Sound, and Enjoyment, I would give this anime a 9 out of 10. It was impressive, but it didn’t give me much of what I wanted. Still, it was somewhat entertaining and loveable forever and ever.

Covers season 1 and 2
J.C. Staff, check. Director Kenichi Kasai with previous slice of life and romance anime work such as Honey and Clover, check. Even the writer and illustrator combo of Ohba Tsugumi and Obata Takeshi, the guys behind Death Note, bring past success to the table.
Bakuman features two kids that want to create a hit manga that will eventually be created into an anime. No doubt this is a nostalgia trip story based on the creator’s as they made into the manga creation industry. The director’s influence from previous work makes its’ mark known here ranging from the pastel colors and pallets tothe late 90’s character designs. Much of the anime besides a duo’s goal to become great mangakas is the romance sub-plot of the duo with their female counterparts. Their love story is a major motivation for Bakuman.


The bromance between Mashiro and Takagi is something of a spectacle, while the story revolves around the motivations and actions of Mashiro. His drive to create a manga to become a hit anime in order to fulfill a non-sensible love struck promise kind of falls into a shounen type anime clashing with shoujo characteristics. Much of the other characters are second nature to what Mashiro himself does ranging from stubborn illustrations to overwork itself. Most of these issues tackled in Bakuman says much about the state of the industry itself. Bakuman clearly clashes with ideals and ideas of what romance is and was and even the characters themselves get called out for it during the journey. While the romance is there for good story intentions, it often feels over used and misguided for the real story being told.


Bakuman is strongest when moving away from any sub-plots and focuses on the core, making a hit manga and the struggles that come with it. Season 1 hits this quite well. However, as the series continues from there is where it seems to slow to a crawl. Sure, waiting on weekly rankings to see where they stand or even waiting to hear back from the board if their manga will make it into the magazine makes for a tight intriguing watch. Unfortunately, character motivations and choices battle with the incredible realistic tone on the industry. It is well done in most aspects, but a realistic pace and portrayal may not make the best entertainment in the long run. That’s what hurts Bakuman the most, not the unrealistic fantasy dream of romance in the sub-plot.


There is no doubt Bakuman comes with frustrations while watching. Also, there is no doubt the third season culminates into something worth the effort, if dying to see how the duo winds up with their manga success. This series is unique and is at least worth the effort of giving a good try.

Since the first episode, it keeps you wanting to come back to see more and more. I finished the 3 seasons in less than a month. 
Good story, even though is a little bit cliché it is enjoyable. The developing of characters throughout the story is great. And there are funny parts, too. A little bit of everything, but for some people maybe they will find it a bit repetitive, if you don't like the theme. 
If you are an artist and like to draw or you would like to become a comic artist or a mangaka, this definitely is your anime. It gives youa lot of motivation to continue practising your skills, it really helps. Also it gives you an insight of the manga industry and editorials.

Bakuman is a masterpiece. There are three seasons to Bakuman and this review will speak to all of them. Bakuman is one of those anime that is so fulfilling throughout the entire 75 episode story that it will leave you feeling complete and satisfied. I have watched anime from all different genre for the last five  years and outside of the typical "masterpieces" that the general public often finds agreement on (think Death Note, Code Geass, etc), I had yet to find a show that is less popular that I consider a true masterpiece. Bakuman changed that for me. There is nothing in anyseason of Bakuman that needed changing - everything comes together throughout the seasons to create a complete and satisfying story that will leave your heart warm and your eyes wet.


{Story} - The story of Bakuman is what created the structure for it to be a masterpiece. Every episode serves a purpose in building up your investment in characters and highlighting key facets of the manga industry. As someone that was previously ignorant of the difficulties and challenges faced by mangaka, Bakuman will draw you into the world of manga and leave you breathless. The story draws you into the creative process and will leave you exhausted alongside the main characters as they fight for serialization and an anime adapation. This anime will make you feel the story like no other.


{Art} - While I am inexperienced in what constitutes "good animation art", the visuals in this anime certainly created an atmosphere that allowed the story and characters to succeed. I would say I have seen more beautiful anime out there, but Bakuman's art felt proper and natural for the setting.


{Sound} - Similar to the art side side, the sound in Bakuman felt right. There was no noise or songs that felt out of place or distracting from the anime. Every song and sound effect added to the ambiance that Bakuman needed to succeed and it did just that.


{Character} - By far and away the strongest point of Bakuman and what filled out the story frame that allowed this anime to become a masterpiece. I often find anime that have many different "main characters" to spread themselves too thin and to draw away from the rest of the story, but every single character in Bakuman served an integral purpose to the overall story. You will care about every character in this story (except maybe Nakai who frustrated the heck out of me) by the time it is finished and understand just how important each person was to the story. I've never felt so heavily invested in over 10 main characters in an anime before - but Bakuman did it in such an excellent fashion that I have zero complaints. I cared more about some of the minor characters in Bakuman due to the way they were developed than I care about most main characters in an average anime.


{Enjoyment} - To put it bluntly, I watched all three seasons of Bakuman (75 episodes) in three days. That's just how incredible the anime was for me. While I tend to binge watch shows, its rare for me to get invested in an anime with more than 25ish episodes and feel the need to watch the next episode immediately. Needless to say, Bakuman is a masterpiece that you will be unable to put down.


{Overall} - Overall I gave Bakuman a 10/10 - a true masterpiece. I felt this anime to be one of the most complete and fulfilling anime that I have ever watched and it will be one of those anime that I binge watch again in the future when I have a hole left in my chest from a less satisfying anime.


Bakuman - a true masterpiece.

So, if you are a fan of anime the chances are that you're a fan of manga as well. If so, Bakuman is defenitly an anime you should consider watching, it tells you everything you could want to know about manga and is filled with dreams, love and friendship.
Story (8):
So, the story for Bakuman is pretty simple; Moritaka Mashiro has long since given up on his childhood dream of becoming a mangaka (manga artist). That is, until his classmate Akito Takagi sees his drawings and proposes that he and Mashiro become a mangaka duo with Mashiro as the illustrator! Eventually,Takagi convinces Mashiro and the twowork towards there dream of making a manga that gets an anime adaptation.Let the games begin.


Art (8):

The art by J.C staff (best known for there slice-of-life works like Tora Dora and Pet Girl Of Sakurasou) was consistent and has a nice style. The character designs were also well done and I felt that overall the art was pretty good.


Characters (9):

The characters were super lovable! Bakuman dealt with a fairly large cast of characters very well. Our main characters Takagi and Mashiro had wonderful personalities and had a developed friendship that felt realistic. The rest of the cast was also amazing; there was Eiji Nizuma who was far from the typical rival character, Miho Azuki and Miyoshi Kaya were also far from the typical love interests. And there are many over character that are far from typical, too many to name, but they are all just as amazing and developed as these!


Sound (6):

To be honest, I really didn't think the music was great. The pieces were mostly flat and un-memorable, nothing much to write home about. Although, this is just my opinion.

Thankfully, the voice acting was amazing. Especially Satoshi Hino (Sayama Ryou in the Code Geass movies) as Takagi and Nobuhiko Okamoto (Obi in Akagami no Shirayuki-hime) as Eiji.


Overall Enjoyment (8):

Overall, as a huge fan of the manga, I think the anime adaptation was very faithful to the manga.

3 Seasons Combined Review
At first i thought that i should watch all seasons and then write a combined review but after it was all done it was too much to write so instead i will do a (Pro/Con) list for the main elements of the show
Story (8/10):
Pros:
- A good take on the Manga industry although i am sure that the real thing is more complicated than this it was good to have some sort of insight (Simplified as it was)
- A good amount of Drama. The whole thing moved to high gear halfway through the second season and it was going up after that. TheRomance idea was extremely far fetched but was still great to watch as the lack of day to day interaction actually made it better and less cliché imo

- Good comedy


Cons:

- Some stuff get a little repetitive

- It was kind of predictable, so there was no suspense factor for me.

- Although the show was trying to show how "cutthroat" the manga industry is. It was extremely lenient with the MC at some points which took away from the realism enjoyment and added to it's predictability I mentioned


Characters (7/10):


Pros:

- A huge cast with many great characters that ranged from completely nuts to simple and lovable

- Kaya Miyoshi (Best Girl) :D

- Kouji Yoshida (Simply loved his scenes) :D


Cons:

- Barely noticeable character main characters growth. The anime (in it's 3 seasons) supposedly spanned 10 years but even to it's last episodes i still felt like i was watching a high school drama

- Everyone is so fuckin understanding o_O I mean what thae actual fuck. I realize that this a Shounen anime but things need to have a limit

- Related to the point above, the show also lacked real assholes. one can have too much "Friendly rivalry" to last a lifetime in this show


Art and Animation (8/10):


Pros:

- For an anime about Manga it offer some really great and different types of art

- Environments and character design was good


Cons:

- It had some issues with size a depth perception


Music & VA (7/10):


Pros:

- Catchy and upbeat OPs and EDs

- Good voice acting


Cons:

- The soundtrack (during the actual anime) was repetitive. I believe it was the same during all three seasons


Effectiveness (7/10):

It was a good and entertaining show with a good amount of drama and comedy and sweet (Although super imaginary) romance but it was "Too Shounen" if this was an actual term

if that aspect was toned down a bit i would have enjoyed a lot more


Overall (7.4/10)

Once in a while you get to stumble upon pretty decent anime. Something that is unconvencional anime, like Bakuman would appear to be if you read synopsis, but sometimes it fails at its uniqueness, like Bakuman did. It was one of those stories that drag you in with promising description, but end up being badlands filled with nothing. Nothing! NOTHING!
Starting with story, we have 2 main characters. These two protagonists meet and decide to chase their dreams of becoming manga artists (mangakas). Not a bad premise if you ask me, because it is something different. Most of anime is battle shounen and this is anice change from time to time... No. This isn't any different from basic generic shounen genre. Don't let the synopsis fool you, because this show is trying to be its shounen's close friend. It's like most fighting shounens minus weapons. They completely missed on the 'romance' part (It is there, I know, but only for total of 20 minutes or less)! They striped themselves off of the romance element and filled it with nothing but unimportant 'dream chase' garbage. Only thing you can experience is watching two high school students overcome their difficulties and inexpierences in the world of manga, while this anime somehow managed to ruin even that. Yes.


The worst part of this anime is its characters. Two guys, two girls. That's main characters, then we have one editor guy and one "villain". Like I said before, this anime tries to push the whole 'shounen' plague on you, so they summon a villain. Yes, an enemy for those two guys fight, because it would be boring otherwise. No, it was boring anyway. Here's why: that enemy is a mere competitor - obviously, it's just school anime, no killing - and he is the most cringiest and worst 'madman genius' type, because that role was pushed onto him. Their rival in manga creation world is simply annoying, embarassing, chlidish and suffers from many psychological disorders. I get it though. They were trying to make that his charm... But it failed incredibly. From a crazy rival who was supposed to be a genius, they made him only annoying and predictably boring.

That wasn't the worst part of the worst part, the characters. The absolute worst place was taken by Miho, love interest of our protagonist. I bailed on the whole romance part since fifth episode - maybe even sooner - but mere character of her and her being in this anime made me almost puke. Classic goody-shoes, shy, spineless girl without character. The worst suffering. *SPOILERS* They kissed. Just kidding. They didn't. You know why? Because she made promise with our protagonist not to date untill they accomplish their dreams. Sure, cute and inevitable wish when you are pursuing your dreams, you want to focus just on that and nothing else. But this anime was put in romance section, so everything they wished for was undeniably  way to make me suffer. While Miho was crybaby and arguably one of the worst characters ever written, her friend Miyoshi - who I deemed the best of them all - was pushed in the corner of the story. And do we give Miyoshi some credits? No, we mostly focus on human garbage disguised as Miho and her male equivalent, Mashiro. While their hearts must've skipped a beat when just being near each other, I sure skipped some of their scenes.


Sound was just average. Nothing special. Opening was the worst garbage I've ever heard in a while and background music was just meh. I'm not gonna say it was all horrible, they could have no music at all, which would be bigger turnoff.


As for art, again, nothing special. Can't say it was bad either.


Now I can't give it half of the stars, because it was different. If I was obsessed with manga it would be definitely more appealing. But I watched it because it was said to be school romance. I expected more, much more.

While this might be garbage for me, I know that many people who are perhaps also younger can enjoy this. Someone who wants to become artist in general, or more specificaly mangaka, this show must be for him. Otherwise it's horrible.

Final rating is 6/10, because I've seen worse. Be warned though and avoid this if you expect above average anime with decent plot.

If you like reading any kind of manga you will love this anime! Especially if you were ever interested in the process of making manga!
Story- The main plot line is about two guys trying to have their manga published and have an anime made based of their manga. It opens up all of the secrets of the manga world and that is truly amazing! Apart from that, there are also great love and friendship plot lines. The story is very positive and inspiring. Honestly, while watching it,I wanted to become a mangaka too more and more. This anime definitely puts you in a right moodand makes you want to be creative.    Even though it's not some kind of action packed story, I was very intrigued by it. I worried about the characters and I got connected to them a lot. Also, I was very satisfied by the ending and I can't wait to start watching other seasons.


Art-  I loved the drawing style of Bakuman. It suited the story perfectly. It was very realistic and on point. Character designs were great, none of the characters seemed to look alike.


Sound-  Seiyuus did an amazing job at portraying characters. There was not that much of a background music,but if there was it was nice. I didn't particularly enjoy the opening song, but I liked the ending.


Characters- all of the characters were very likable and lovely. I can not forget to mention how Takagi Akito reminds me of Light Yagami. But I guess there was some sense in making Takagi so similar looking. My favorite character is Nizuma Eiji (even though he is a supporting character) He is just a genius upcoming mangaka and also he's very funny and has something unusual and quirky about him that makes him very likable. All characters were on point and developed very well and I liked them a lot.


Enjoyment-  I enjoyed Bakuman a lot! I think that anyone can like this,no matter what genre they usually go for. It's an amazingly told story that captivates you. I marathoned this anime in 1,5 days, because I just couldn't stop watching it!   Also, I believe that even those,who don't like anime that match may enjoy this anime,because it shows the world of anime and manga so perfectly that you just can not be left without any emotions and feelings to it.

 I highly recommend Bakuman!

The story is about the boy who has nothing to do in particular in his daily school life. he has a crush on a classmate girl since elementary school now in middle school. 
One day the first rank student ask him to join to be mangaka(manga creator).
Then, he accept it not right away though.

Their first manga is "futari no chikyuu" can be translated as The Two Earth.
This anime makes me think how dreams should be accomplished through many possible ways which aren't that impossible.
The first impression that igot from watching BAKUMAN is i can do whatever i thing that time. that's why i try to watch all of the episode in one-go.\n

Do visit my blog if you can: http://iseedeadanime.wordpress.com/2011/04/10/bakuman-a-charming-mangaka-story/

The story of Bakuman follows a 9th grade boy Mashiro Moritaka who's dream is to become a great manga publisher and to have an anime series put out to have the love of his life marry him. This story is about following your dreams and working hard to achieve them. 
Now, I won't waste your time with a summary, because you can read the synopsis on the main page. However, this story is very interesting and it really gave me an insight on the manga world and how everything works. Though it may be questionable, due to the fact that i did not know anythingabout how manga and anime were made beforehand, i found this series very intriguing and informative. So let's say this anime offered me some insight, correct me if im wrong (ignorance is bliss).\n\n
This anime goes down as one of the most interesting series i have ever watched because of how in depth the characters are, as well as how interesting the story is. Anyone who is interested in the nature of manga or anime, should watch this. I highly recommend it.

Bakuman really is the anime (and manga) for the hardcore and well-read manga lover! 
The jokes and references to old and new manga (Fu-sion Ha!) will make you laugh or search out old issues of Jump. But even if you are not well-versed in all the mentioned mangas, you will still enjoy what is going on and learn a lot. 
This anime/manga also teaches a great deal about the industry and how manga artists, theirs editors and the weekly magazines work. Characters in the story open up commentary on how the stories are chosen for the magazine, explaining the Jump questionnaires and decision making process,and even the inequities and problems some of the current methods have on the manga selection process. \n\n
The anime emphasizes the innocent romance side story more than the manga does, but it is still fine for the Not Mushy Romantics.

I’m always been in love with Death Note. It literally changes how I perceive life. Even after so many years, the overwhelming experience watching it still lingers within me. So when I heard that Tsugumi Ohba and Takeshi Obata are doing another story I was more that delighted. I was dying with so much anticipation. 
There’s a long review coming………
About the STORY
After watching anime and reading mangas for more than a decade, I learn to truly appreciate the people who create such magnificent creation. Mangakas are the ones who give birth to them. You can even say that they are the main reason why Iam so fascinated with animes and mangas. So even before watching this series, I definitely admire them. However, watching this series makes me understand mangakas in whole different way. This series shows the weight and gravity of making such a creation. It is very much knowledgeable because it is shown in details. From how one story is given birth to how it is polish to serialization and to being adapted into an anime. But more importantly, the story is about dreaming and having a goal. You will learn that things would not usually go your way, not by just pure effort. A little gamble and pure luck is needed also. This is what I love with Ohba’s story. It is not just entertaining or being interesting but rather, you can definitely learn something from it. 


About the CHARACTERS

The characters are very much realistic. Their characters are something that we could really relate to in real life. It is very inspiring not only to aspiring mangakas but with people who have their own dreams as well.  Though, I think that the relationship of Saikou and Azuki is really weird yet somewhat original. I think it is not a great option not to meet until making their dreams come true. I know a lot of people who does that and by the time they are at the peak of their careers, they already forgotten why they’ve dreamt in the first place and its already too late. Yes, love comes with different forms but still. I also think that getting your dreams come true in a very short time is somehow unrealistic. I mean it’s really hard making dreams come true and worst; they sometimes never come true let alone make them at a very short time. I believe anything in haste makes waste. Let me just mention, that the character of Nizuma is very likeable just like L in Death Note. For some reason, the mangakas love to have a certain character that is weird yet so genius. They are also the ones who inspires other characters.


About the ANIMATION

The illustration is somewhat different from Obata’s usual artwork but the touch and trademark is definitely visual. I just love how Obata gives life to the characters.


I am not Japanese but I am very much aware how popular Shounen Jump is. Almost all of my favorite animes has been serialized by Shounen Jump so I have a vague idea how the magazine works. But after watching this, I learn a lot. This series shows how the Shounen Jump works and that is very knowledgeable. However, as far as exciting is concern, this series is lacking so much. People who would really relate to the story are mostly from Japan and very few with other nationality. What I’m trying to say is that internationally it would be hard for viewers to comprehend the details of the storyline and plot. Even I, who have knowledge with it, had a hard time comprehending the storyline. It is pretty much interesting but it also has the tendency to get so boring. 


Wow! It was quiet hard giving comments considering this is about Mangakas. Learning about them in a whole different way, makes the review pretty hard.

For every Japanese teenager who wanted to write a manga, here’s the shounen version of that! So, yeah, this is basically a show about teenage boys wanting to be manga-ka. But, in order for this to be accessible, the idea of art is sidestepped. In Bakuman, creating manga, shounen manga at least, is basically a series of popularity battles, with the ultimate goal basically being voted #1 in the magazine that they run in. There’s some lip service paid to alternative manga, but the question of art never really comes up. Which is both damning and myopic in equal measures. This is probably the mostinnocent thing I saw all year, too. The romance, at least the main one, is so ridiculously “innocent” that it almost becomes like this weird abstract concept of what a first love should be. Which again ties back into its relatively idealized take on its characters, emotions and their milieu. Regardless, this is still heaps of fun.\n\n

This anime is a MASTERPIECE.I typically don't really like slice of life anime but this was just amazing. 
Story (10/10): The show's story is really simple. Two friends decide that they want to become the greatest mangakas that Japan has ever seen. The simplicity is what truly made this amazing and enjoyable. The anime showed the different challenges that the characters, Mashiro and Takagi, had to face, and it definitely had shounen aspects in it by the way that they never gave up. 
Character (10/10): Each of the characters were really likable. Mashiro and Takagi were such funny characters and the way they never gaveup was admirable. I believe that it was not only the main characters that made the show amazing but also the supporting characters. Each of the characters had such interesting quirks and characteristics. \n
Sound and Art (10/10): The first opening was really catchy, and the soundtracks were really good. They really fit the mood well. The art was really good with each background being defined clearly by its colors. \n
Overall, I would highly recommend this to anyone that likes slice of life anime.

Bakuman isn't about fan service, so if you're looking for a romance story where two characters fall in love and start making out, you're in the wrong place. I've read comments before about how people were pissed off with how slow and non-existent Mashiro's relationship with Azuki is, though most people probably won't have much of a problem with the amount of the story that's covered in this series, at least. Bakuman doesn't have a whole lot of action either; I'd say it's not really suited for 12 year olds. If your favourite series is Bleach or DBZ, you should turn back now. 
-Story-
If youenjoy anime, what's not to like? Bakuman gives a very in-depth view of what it takes to create good manga while also giving a little info on related stuff in the industry, i.e. voice actors and anime. Many anime/manga fans start to draw in "anime style", some of them even create their own independent manga. Bakuman shows you that there's always something that can be improved in both the story and art, that originality is important, and that a job of just drawing pictures all day isn't as easy as one might think. 

Although the series doesn't spend that much time at the school, the series has a school life and slice of life air about it, which I enjoy. It isn't just educational, but also entertaining. It's got dreams that the average viewer can probably relate to; it's got pure love where material things and using each other for sexual urges have no role; it's got suspense. The end of each episode will often leave you inspired and wanting to see the next one.


-Art-

The animation is smooth and I think the artstyle is interesting how all the characters are really skinny; it's sorta like xxxHolic, but without the freakishly tall part. The art was just good overall. I thought the detail on Takagi's hair was pretty disappointing, though. In the manga, it's just way more defined and the style of it is unique. Here, however, it looks like a cheapened version of Light's hair from Death Note. 


-Sound-

I dislike Mashiro's voice; he just sounds really wimpy. I also dislike the opening theme; I think it just sounds really gay. I think male singers are fine, even some Japanese boybands... I just generally like Japanese music since it tends to sound more like disco or dance music, but this opening theme sounds as gay as American boybands. I could let the opening theme for Itazura na Kiss grow on me, but not this one; I usually just skipped over it. 

Everyone else's voices were fair enough and both ending themes were cool. I liked how the ending themes started playing a little bit before it got to the credits; it was timed well. The rest of the music in the series was alright; I guess it fits the slice of life genre. 


-Characters-

No complaints here. I particularly like Fukuda, how he's just as much of a badass as the characters are in his manga. I also like that his editor is pretty similar despite how he tries to tell Fukuda to be more polite and stuff; they're just a good match. Some characters are skeptical of each other at first and gradually warm up in a convincing way. 


-Enjoyment-

It bothered me how the series was putting so much focus on Koogy right from the very start. They kept having girls here and there talk about Koogy and they had his posters all over the place and stuff. Having read the manga, it just made it very obvious to me that the final showdown would be with Koogy. I guess it's sort of okay for them to make us see that it would be a problem to face a celebrity who has so much support, but to me it just felt a little too blatant. Same goes for how they were dropping hints about Hiramaru near the end. Other than that, each episode was fun to watch and I never thought it felt like a grind. 


The manga's a bit better, but this is a good anime version that stays pretty true to the manga. The story is interesting and there are no fillers. If you've ever wondered how anime/manga is created or if you want to draw your own manga, you should watch Bakuman.

Mashiro Moritaka- “My uncle never told me to become a mangaka. I'm drawing manga because I want to. A dream isn't something someone tells you to go for. It's something you fulfil on your own." 
 AMAZING, FANTASTIC & SUPERB.
These are just a few words to describe how I feel about Bakuman.
Story: 10/10
Mashiro is a talented drawer whereas Akito Takagi is a promising writer. While still in middle school they decide they want to become the greatest mangaka’s together in all of Japan. Under the pen name Ashirogi Muto their aim is to create a popular manga series and get serialized with Weekly Shounen jackso that readers across Japan can read their stories. 


Throughout the 1st season you will see their journey to getting serialized will not be easy and their dedication and determination may not be enough to get them ahead. They will face many obstacles and challenges as they try to get to the top, but as we go on we learn that these two will not easily give up on fulfilling their dreams as well as a promise that Mashiro made which they set out from the beginning. 


One aspect that I loved about this show was the process of how manga is created. From getting ideas down and generating a storyboard to drawing the characters, background and text to finally presenting your work to an editor with the opportunity of it being selected and getting serialized. You really understand and get the feel of what mangaka’s really do just to get serialized and even when you do it just gets even harder as you have to keep working to ensure your series doesn’t get cancelled. 


As a big fan of manga myself I noticed a lot of references to other popular manga series which is great to see as it gets the characters talking about what their favourite series are and how manga influenced them in deciding to become mangaka’s themselves. 


Art: 10/10


I found the art to be really good. I don’t know if it’s just me, but every time I look at Mashiro’s dark hair I just love looking at it due to the sharpness at the tips of his hair and the blue streaks compliment his black hair really well. I especially love how they are able to change to different art styles when it comes to the characters creating their manga. I find it amazing how they are able to do that for each manga they are creating. Seeing Mashiro draw with his pen made it seem so realistic and really shows off what a professional is capable of. Each character has their own unique designs that I love and their random quirks when they react to something is always hilarious to see.       


Sound: 10/10


The first opening song “Blue Bird" by Kobukuro is fantastic and after listening to it I automatically fell in love with it and is probably my favourite Bakuman song. It really sets the tone for the show and is just so relaxing to watch and listen to. The background music when Ashirogi Muto  succeeds really gets me excited to cheer for them as they are one step closer to their dreams coming true.  


Character: 10/10


Both Mashiro & Akito are fantastic leads that have set out goals that they want to achieve so they can fulfil their dreams. They are ordinary people like you & me that have decided to devote their lives to creating manga so that their work can reach people across Japan and possibly the world. I find this truly inspiring as they never give up and will always continue to do what they love no matter what. Mashiro is an amazing drawer who really puts in the effort to bring his characters to life. Seeing them drawn & animated is really cool to see. Akito is always thinking of ideas and is constantly brainstorming on what could potentially be their next big hit. He even goes so far as to write up drafts that are only worthy of Mashiro and not just throw any random ideas at him. 


There are only a few select females in this anime, but I will mention the two that greatly impact both Mashiro & Akito. 


Azuki Miho is a promising seiyu (voice actor) and made a promise to Mashiro that she will accept his marriage proposal as soon as both their dreams come true. However they are not to contact each other until their dreams are fulfilled. Even though they cannot directly meet face-to-face she is always thinking about him & supporting his dream. 


Kaya Miyoshi is Azuki’s best friend and is a big support for Ashirogi Muto. She sometimes helps out with ideas for their manga & usually assists in inking & toning. She is loud & outspoken and says what’s on her mind. She is someone you would definitely want around as she is so caring and early on has feelings for Akito. 


There are plenty of rival characters that Ashirogi Muto will face as they all compete to be number #1. You would think that most of their rivals are only looking out for themselves and are only aiming for the #1 spot no matter what. However as we go on you find out that everyone is supporting each other and they all want to help each other get serialized while maintaining that competitiveness. One rival I found interesting was the genius high school mangaka Niizuma Eiji. At first I found him quite annoying and over the top, but I was pleasantly surprised later on at how much he drove Ashirogi Muto to improve and develop their own manga style. He saw them as rivals that had the potential to beat him and occasionally gave them advice. Turns out I freaking love this character so don’t judge him too quickly. 


Enjoyment: 10/10


I thoroughly enjoyed this anime. Learning about manga and what goes into creating one and then the steps to getting serialized I found interesting and gave me a whole new appreciation for manga. The time and effort that is put into each chapter by the mangaka’s and the stress they put onto their bodies just to meet deadlines. All the characters had their own personalities which I loved and the comedy was hilarious. Most importantly was seeing Ashirogi Muto work hard to achieve their dreams and continue to move forward.     


Overall: 10/10


Overall this is a masterpiece of an anime. As a whole this has entered into one of my favourite anime’s of all time. I would definitely recommend this to anyone that wants to know about manga and what goes into getting serialized. Great lead as well as supporting characters. The music and art is fantastic and their journey to being #1 is something you want to see them achieve by the end of it.     


So the next time you read manga in a library/store or decide to purchase some just maybe think about how much time and effort the mangaka put in to get their story across to their readers.

Okay... First off, if you are not a seasoned anime viewer/manga reader, do not bother... YET! 
Now, if you enjoy anime/manga, you will definitely enjoy and most likely have a hard time stopping yourself from watching non-stop. 
If you are indeed a seasoned anime viewer like myself AND appreciate the work of the author and/or artist... you will enjoy this story that will most likely give you the most realistic feel or view of what it is like to be a manga artist or author alike. It is very intense in it's own kind of way and there is a little bit of romanticism aswell but, in a very prude way :P

This shit. This shit right here is so fucking fire. It legitimately inspires me, and the series only gets better as time goes on. If you ever needed to be inspired to make art or even follow your dreams, watch this. On top of that inspirational stuff, it also delivers its message quite well. It creates multiple layers of motivation and perfectly captures the desire and drive many artists have or want to have in regards to making art. Its conflicts can feel a bit rushed at times, but it does add substance to the show, so I'm giving it a pass. It makes alltheir struggles seem more real due to how it develops the characters and portrays their emotions and motivations throughout the show. Like holy shit though, it sucks you in with a seemingly simple plot above and beyond. It is honestly beautiful to see them follow their dreams for each of their individual reasons. I'd go into specifics, but if anyone actually reads this I want them to be sucked in and experience their development as I have. Honestly though, this is one of the few things I have experienced that has actually moved me to make an actual change in my life.

Story: 9 - Moritaka Mashiro is a pretty much normal high schooler except the matter of fact that he can draw well whereas Akito Takagi is overall intelligent and is an aspiring writer. After pestering Mashiro for a while Takagi managed to convince Mashiro to join him in becoming a mangaka duo after which Mashiro promised made a promise with the girl he liked which is that he with Takagi will make a manga so great that it will have a anime adaption while she will become agreat seiyuu who will voice the female protagonist in their anime. People who liked: Hataraki Man,Mangaka-san to Assistant-san to,Chihayafuru and Genshiken will like this series due to similar elements.

there are many aspects of this anime that I like so I'll get over with them quickly; It's made by the creators of Death Note a anime that I seriously like, the premise is interesting and it's handled well during the series, it doesn't get melodramatic for a highschool student drama (Thank god), it keeps a nice contrast between seriousness and comedy and it's very grounded in realism to give the expectator a clear view of the world of the manga artists which makes this series even more recommended for someone who wants to be a manga artist.
Now what I don't like of the animeis some mishandlings with the transition from comic to animation, this series has A LOT of dialog and it feels quite uncanny when characters stand still for so long talking making me wonder how do they even breathe. I guess you can say that I'm exaggerating but the thing is that for animation it's better to cut down the dialog for more exposition since everything is in motion you can tell more through expresion and atmosphere rather than words only, people who watch TV don't have the patience for dialog as someone who reads books or comic.


This leads me to this conclusion, it's better to read the manga not only because it gets rid of that uncanny feeling I explained earlier but also because character models and commedic expresions have better impact on the manga which is weird considering that it doesn't have the advantage of motion


Also one last thing, this isn't really a spoiler but don't set your expectations to high on the ending. It's very anticlimatic and it does not give a clear vision to what happens to most of the characters

Bakuman is a really inspiring & motivating series. I've started off the series with concrete belief that this series will definitely be an awesome one because of the faith I have with the original creator, and it did not disappoint me. I watched this series in an on-and-off basis, but it always manages to impress me, making me to stick myself in front of the screen for a full 20 minutes. The most awesome(?) part is when the series tends to end one episode with cliffhangers (especially when some results are going to be announced) and you will go like "aww man, don't stop there!Now where's the next episode?". Somehow, it's perfect in building up tension and then holding you at the edge of the mountain preventing you to continue moving. I find the tension and psychological headaches worked well on me. 


I've mentioned that the series is really inspiring & motivating. And I mean it. You follow the dream of two teenagers; you see how determined they are in realizing & moving towards their dreams; you see how they got up again & again even after one & another failures. Somehow, the spirit just blends in to you. It affected me in a good way. Sometimes it makes me guilty - "what am I doing here slacking my time off when I can actually work as hard as them?" - despite being a really egoistic person & a person with extreme high self-esteem myself, I have to admit that I'm beaten - be it fictional or not.


I'm really impressed. Watch it to get inspired & motivated. And I'm moving on to the next season.

Review 12: Bakuman (Get your pens out)
In this review i'll be explaining what Bakuman is and the characters init as people are getting to confused with Bakuman and Bakugan which annoys me and my friends at school very much. -_-.
First of all the series of books is all about two best friends who have brilliant imaginations and wish to create a book together for Shonen Jump.
When making some prototypes for Shonen Jump they see all of the highs and lows of being a writers and artist's and how much they need to do to just be in the magazine monthly. Whilst balancing high schoollife and a producers life they realise that their can only be one route for both of them, which means hard decisions and risks that they have to take that would hopefully make their rest of their lives the best it could be.


Akito Takagi: He is one of the main characters for the Bakuman anime and manga series. At the begginning of the series we see him as a 14 year old high school student. His nickname through out the series is Shuujin and as he meets another boy in his class named Moritaka he realises his amazing drawing skills and potential as an artist so he asks if they can help each other out. Hes the most intelligent in his class and gets top grades throughout the school every term, with his intelligence on his side he becomes the maker of the story lines and character profiles which Moritaka than works on to make the stories that they put together come to life. Akito's girlfriend is annoyingly loud and makes Moritaka a bit more frustrated whenever she comes round to their work room.


Moritaka Mashiro: Is really the main character that all of the attention is focused on throughout the series. The series of books starts off with him being 14 just like Akito. They both meet each other by being put in to the same class and had no contact before that which adds a bit of a mysterious side to it as they are complete strangers up until this moment in their lives. He isn't as intelligent as Akito but is more creative as he always draws and doodles in lessons so his grades are always a little bit lower then Akito. As Moritaka is in to art he usually expresses himself through the drawings that he does in class, especially to one girl (who i will not be mentioning), she wants to pursue the dream of becoming a voice over actress and as Moritaka wants to become a artist they realise that their dreams are to different so they try to maintain it for as long as they can, which eventually turns out to be perfect for them both.




The story than goes on for them as they see all of the ups and downs that any other artist would expect to see and witness at some point in their ives.


you wouldn't expect the creators at shonen Jump to reveal so much about how to get into the magazine and how it all works in the offices but they reveal a lot about it all and also mentioning the names of some rivals that they will come across at some point which brings the two infamous creators down just a little bit, but they get back up on to thier feet fighting once again to win their place in the magazine and become the artists that they've always wanted to be.


In the second book in the series you realise that it isn't all fun and games for them all as it's the middle of their term at school people aren't all to comfrotable when they see their names on the back of the weekly Shonen Jump magazine, boys in their classes seem to think that it isn't likely that their dreams will ever come true and that they will fail just like their dreams are.....But when some children in their classes adjust to the fact that they aren't going to give up any time soon some start to admire it and start to become fans of their short stories.


As i am still watching and reading the series of Bakuman i don't know a lot that happens after the 6th book which makes me feel a little bit down as i could tell you more about the series, i'll be updating on the series when i have time to and will be explaining more about what happens in each book.
